text: I emailed this out but it doesn't hurt to share here: <http://www.eventbrite.com/e/show-tell-dan-cassaro-tickets-11334272113>

attachments.title: Show & Tell: Dan Cassaro
attachments.text: Be Honest is open to the public from 6-8, but you MUST have a ticket to attend Dan's talk which happens from 8-9. We are so excited to have Dan Cassaro as our Be Honest 2014 Guest Speaker!Dan Cassaro is a graphic designer, illustrator, and native New Yorker living and working in Brooklyn, New York. He runs his own studio and is work focuses on type, lettering, logo design, and powerful 70s rock and roll.  Dan Cassaro was named an ADC Young Gun in 2011 and his work and projects have received accolades from many publications such as The New Yorker, The Wall Street Journal, Fast Company, Rolling Stone, Esquire, and The New York Magazine along with many other major design and illustration publications. Welcome Dan! Dan's talk is sponsored by Scout Books, The Pressure and Virb. Thank you!

attachments.title: Designing for Performance
attachments.text: As a web designer, you have tough choices to make when it comes to weighing aesthetics and performance. This practical book helps you approach a new project with page speed in mind, and shows you h...

text: I'm very interested in this "shows you know how to test and benchmark which design choices are most important."
Typography question: Are em-dashes supposed to be used without spaces before and after when placed between two words? This is the way I remember being taught but I'm second-guessing now.
technically i think yes
but i usually end up adding spaces in... or custom kerning if i can
I always want there to be spaces, but it gets so wide with two full spaces and an em-dash.
Custom kerning would be nice if time allowed.
right.
Are two spaces and an en-dash totally forbidden?
for online text its obviously way more annoying
The "British way"
whats the usage?
en-dashes should only be used for denoting number ranges
yea what is this for?
I've read two spaces and an en-dash is occasionally used in GB
don't even get me started on the brits, trent
I like it that way...
"...he turns redder and redder until—POP!—your bag is ready"
is that an em or an en?
They should be em-dashes
I just copy and pasted
"...he turns redder and redder until – POP! – your bag is ready"
thats with ens
hm
I don't use ens like that because I've been mocked by veteran designers for it.
hahahaha
that makes me want to use them
i actually feel like the ens allow the word POP! to.... pop more.
That was just the first example I found to show the usage I'm referring to.
I'm just seeing a lot of inaccuracies on this in our pitch decks and blog posts.
i would say going forward we should do an em dash and custom insert a bit of space before and after it.
if we're talking about indesign /keynote docs, anyway
Even though that's ideal, I feel that's a little much to ask...
If it's space or no space, which would it need to be?
I would say we should be consistent about it, and beyond that use a format that reads the best
I ask that because I feel custom spaces will end up being inconsistent too.
agreed
right
well i think it depends on the font
whether we use a space or not.
i know some rules were created, and followed for typewriters, but in digital it's awkward. Like double space after sentence. I wouldn't be surprised if em-dashes follow that.
if we're talking blog posts, i think Merriweather could use a space on either side
you can look at both type books, Bringhurst and I have the "they mac is not a typewriter" book
i've always wondered, but think you can do what you want. creative license plus web. Now if you were setting this for a book, that would probably be different
for my part - and this is more of a language style than a design thing - I'd say that when you're using the dash as an interruption, as you are with the "pop" I'd us no space.
when you're using them as a replacement for a parenthetical - as I do too much - I'd add the space. In part because in this case you're trying pull out the parenthetical idea
but again - this more about language than about layout

"Em dashes are set with no space before or after the dash. This bothers many people, though, because the dash tends to bump into the letters. So add a tiny bit of space on either side by kerning. But if you insert an entire word space before and after the dash, you exacerbate the interruption in the flow of text."
—Beyond: The Mac is Not a Typewriter
Interesting
I understand all points of view on it.
I guess you can just pick something and stick with it.
yeah
i'd say for things like blog posts we should just pick one- space or no space
i dont think a custom character is an option from a UX standpoint
Matt and I were talking about attempting to create a CSS rule or something to know to add hair spacing before and after em-dashes.
Not sure if that's possible.
yeah if the CSS can do the work that would be cool
that always runs the risk of someone adding spaces in anyway
We make a PSA about it.
for sure, but people dont always remember things like that :grinning:
but yea, whatever you decide , definitely PSA
well
if we're going to be all fancy about it, I bet we could add a script when new copy is saved in the CMS that strips out the spaces around em dashes
and then have CSS add back in the spacing we need
What whao
I want that.
A file was shared
I mean - I know that is a thing that is possible to do. The effort involved with out specific situation, I cannot speak to
you know who's always up for a challenge? GASTON
My guess is that if there's nothing weird about our set up its like an hour for him to do it
rip through the text search for em dashes
and then just deleting the spaces before and after
Been heads down on Trapit for the last hr. Catching up on this thread before I respond...
oh nothing - Im just signing you up to do a bunch of work
haha
thats okay, right?
Story of my life.
When are you going to share the Story of Your Life? I was waiting for it at Show and Tell.
same here
ha
So we could do something where JS wraps every EM dash with a span and gives is a class. Then we can use that in CSS to add that space.
Dodging the Life Story...
But I like the idea. Sounds simple enough.
that shit cray
If we're talking Galapagos we could ask Scott/Jenny to do that on the CMS side of things so things are a bit cleaner.
RE: Story of My Life. Been thinking about possible chapters.
The Time I stayed in the house of a former's Hitler's  Youth house in South Africa.
The time I got mugged in Amsterdam.
The guy in my hometown's neighborhood  who wore a white suit and hat every day whose nickname was "El Nazi."
THats a great nickname
I'd read it.
Can we design a long-form web article for it?
Ha, for sure.
with well spaced em dashes
Can that be that title? "Well Spaced Em Dashes"
"and also Nazis"
Yes.
Well Spaced Nazis
You're like a typographic Indiana jones
With less charm and funny retorts.
but with a cool hat and whip
I assume any way
